images.caption: Figure 1:Inference scaling beyond increasing denoising steps.We demonstrate the performance with respect to FID‚Üìbold-‚Üì\boldsymbol{\downarrow}bold_‚Üì, IS‚Üëbold-‚Üë\boldsymbol{\uparrow}bold_‚Üëon ImageNet, and CLIPScore‚Üëbold-‚Üë\boldsymbol{\uparrow}bold_‚Üë, Aesthetic Score‚Üëbold-‚Üë\boldsymbol{\uparrow}bold_‚Üëon DrawBench. Our search framework exhibits substantial improvements in all settings over purely scaling NFEs with increasing denoising steps.

Figure 2:Illustration of Search Algorithms.Left:Random Searchselects the best sample according to the verifier score and rejects the rest.Center:Zero-Order SearchsamplesNùëÅNitalic_Ncandidates in the neighborhood of the pivot noise at each step, and selects the best one according to the verifier to continue the search from.Right:Search over Pathssample noises at intermediate sampling steps to add to current samples to expand the sampling trajectories, and select the best one to continue the search.

Figure 3:Performances of Oracle Verifiers.Random Search with FID and IS on ImageNet.Inference Computeis given by the total NFEs devoted to denoising steps and search; the starting points of all curves in each and the following figures denote only devoting NFEs to denoising steps and 0 NFEs in search.

Figure 4:Performances of Supervised Verifiers.Random Search with CLIP and DINO on ImageNet across different classifier-free guidance weights.CLIP-ZeroShotrefers to using the logits output by the CLIP zero-shot classifier formulated with Prompt Engineering, andDINO-LinearHeadrefers to using the pre-trained linear classifier provided byOquab et¬†al. [53].

Figure 5:Performances of Self-Supervised Verifiers.Left: correlation between CLIP and DINO feature similarity score and their classification logits;Right: Random Search with CLIP and DINO feature similarity score as verifiers across different classifier-free guidance weight.

Figure 6:Performances of Search Algorithms.We fix the verifier to be DINO-LinearHead and investigate the FID and IS of Zero-Order Search and Search over Paths on ImageNet. For each algorithm, we further demonstrate the relationship betweenNùëÅNitalic_Nand their performances.

Figure 8:Performances of Search with FLUX.1-dev at inference-time.We fix the search budget to be3840384038403840NFEs with random search, and demonstrate the relative performance gain (%) with generation without any search budget.

Figure 9:Scalability of search with FLUX.1-dev on DrawBench.We use random search with Verifier Ensemble to obtain the results, and demonstrate the relative performance gain (%) with generation without any search budget. Similar scaling behavior to ImageNet setting is observed across different metrics.

Figure 10:Performance of scaling compute for single search iteration.We use the SiT-XL model, fix the denoising budget to250250250250NFE, and demonstrate the performance differences with respect to the NFEs devoted to a single search iteration.

Figure 11:Performance of our search methods across different model sizes (SiT-{B,L,XL}) on ImageNet. We use the best set up for FID and IS separately.Left: ZO-4 with DINO-LinearHead.;Right: Random Search with DINO-LinearHead.

Figure 12:Performance of tuning additional parameters for algorithms.Left: Zero-Order Search with step
sizesŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª;Right: Search Over Paths with lengthsLùêøLitalic_L. We use SiT-XL and fix the verifier to be the classification logits from DINO.
Figure 13:Performance of Random Search on ImageNet against DINO and CLIP classification logits.We use random search on the SiT-XL model and report FID, IS, Precision, and Recall.

Figure 14:Comparison between Zero-Order and First-Order Search.We use the SiT-XL model and fix the verifier to be the DINO-LinearHead. The Inference Compute is aligned via the rough estimation of cost(backward)‚àºsimilar-to\sim‚àº3√ó\times√ócost(forward).
Figure 15:From Left to Right: Correlation of CLIP, DINO, and SigLIP feature similarity score with CLIPScore. All points are generated from FLUX.1-dev.
